mechanoreception.notes: Pseudoscorpions generally rely on tactile hairs (setae) to detect vibrations and air currents, crucial for prey detection and navigation. Presence inferred from general pseudoscorpion biology.

chemoreception.notes: Pseudoscorpions use chemoreceptors on their pedipalps and legs to detect chemical cues, aiding in prey location, mate finding, and environmental assessment. Presence inferred from general pseudoscorpion biology.

vision.notes: The presence and functionality of eyes in Chernetidae are not explicitly mentioned. Many pseudoscorpions have simple eyes (ocelli), but their role in this family needs further investigation.
